instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2523: What is 820-2523? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-2877: What is 820-2877? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.D6990: What is D6990? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input, can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.C7771: What is C7771? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2330 and 820-2532 logic boards that often dies and causes PP1V05_S5_MCP or PP1V05_S5 to be 0.331v instead of 1.05v. If heating this cap restores voltage to this rail, replace.
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PWRBTN_L: What is PWRBTN_L? PWRBTN_L Is an abbreviation of PM_PWRBTN_L which refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> super strange problem
threads.message:
2523 intermittent green light
<CHIP>U6990</CHIP> shorted,
<CHIP>U6990</CHIP> replaced with one from an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2877</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (same pinout)
output pin 4 now is 3.42V
ppbus 12.61
i think the problem may be smc communication?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> super strange problem
threads.message:
Crap under SMC/around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>? Known good magsafe board? <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>?
If <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> was really shorted there would be no green light at all.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> super strange problem
threads.message: smc clear, <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> clear, known good, <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> 3.374V@<RESISTOR>R6929</RESISTOR>, agreed, changed adapters now have green light, no change to other symptoms

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> super strange problem
threads.message: You didn't mention any other symptoms.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> super strange problem
threads.message: sorry, there isnt any, what would you look for next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> super strange problem
threads.message:
Intermittent meaning green light stops randomly or it's blinking?

Since <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> was shot, nothing funky in this area? <DIODE>D6990</DIODE> and resistors.Traces for onewire circuit.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> super strange problem
threads.message: there is no <DIODE>D6990</DIODE> on this board, i think green light was the charger or dc-in board, but it didnt change anything

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> super strange problem
threads.message: You start the topic by saying no green light. Then it has a green light and ask for more advice? What is the problem, green light was fixed. Use 85W charger and need to short power pads on these boards.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> super strange problem
threads.message: green light is on, but the problem is still not fixed, what do you want me to say?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> super strange problem
threads.message:
[QUOTE="peterfixit, post: 19457"]there is no <DIODE>D6990</DIODE> on this board, i think green light was the charger or dc-in board, but it didnt change anything[/QUOTE]

Maybe another D6xxx label on this old C2D board. I don't have the schematic but pretty sure if you look pp3v42 power supply circuit you will find a dual switching mode diode. But if you fixed green light, it s not anymore relevant.

If intermittent green light is fixed, and you are using 85w charger and you short <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> pads or use a keyboard to power on the board and it still doesn't power on, then it's time to check further power rails.

What about <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> output voltage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> super strange problem
threads.message: What problem? Original post only mentions green light issue.....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> super strange problem
threads.message: ok, the problem is no power, not turning on

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> super strange problem
threads.message: Since you changed the adapter, is it a REAL ORIGINAL 85W one? Battery charging? Does it power off a charged battery? Must short power pads on these boards.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> super strange problem
threads.message: yes genuine 85w charger, no battery to test with but power at battery connector is 0.15v on ppvbatt, on <TRANSISTOR>Q7035</TRANSISTOR> i get 15v on input and 0.6v on output but is not shorted to ground, <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> does nothing

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> super strange problem
threads.message: <SIGNAL>P3V3_S5</SIGNAL>? <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>?

threads.message: <SIGNAL>P3V3_S5</SIGNAL> at <CAPACITOR>C7750</CAPACITOR> is 3.3v   <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 3.395v at <RESISTOR>R5085</RESISTOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> super strange problem
threads.message: Voltage at <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR>? <SIGNAL>PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> toggling if you short power pad?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> super strange problem
threads.message: 1.070V at <CAPACITOR>C7771</CAPACITOR> I cant find TP[1]<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, the tp doesnt line up with anything on the boardview , the only other places it goes is under the cpu and smc

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> super strange problem
threads.message: Landrex gives me probe 1083 right on the other side of the SMC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> super strange problem
threads.message: rtg is 27.93k/0.931V when high, 26.96k/0.914V when low

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> super strange problem
threads.message: No idea what you mean. I asked if the signal toggles when you press the power button.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> super strange problem
threads.message: and im not sure exactly what you mean, i dont have a scope, all i can tell you is something happens on that line when the <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> pads are shorted, so im giving you the resistance to ground and diode mode to ground on the test point

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> super strange problem
threads.message: You should not measure resistance or diode with power applied. You should clearly be able to see the voltage drop and come back when you press power button.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> super strange problem
threads.message: i did see that

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> super strange problem
threads.message: Just out of interest... Did you happen to buy your "genuine" charger from Amazon or eBay? I bought 4 chargers from these fuckers 2 of which died and 1 would not power a board without battery. At least one of them works. They all have a lovely Apple logo on them and all say 85W and look the part but they don't do what they should.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2523</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> super strange problem
threads.message: Get a charged battery and see if it charges and powers on from that.
